STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: Now I'll select treatments based on current clinical guidelines. - First-line treatment per guidelines: Empiric intravenous antibiotics targeting common pathogens. - Supporting evidence: Prompt IV antibiotic therapy reduces complication risk, preserves vision, and addresses the infectious etiology. - Patient-specific considerations: The systemic illness (possibly hantavirus) may influence immune response; caution if leukopenia or coagulopathy exists. - Contraindications or cautions: Watch for allergic reactions; avoid unnecessary delays in antibiotics.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: If medications are appropriate, I'll select based on efficacy and safety. - Primary medication choice: Empiric IV antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone plus clindamycin. - Rationale for selection: Ceftriaxone covers common bacterial pathogens including Streptococcus and Staphylococcus; clindamycin adds anaerobic coverage and anti-inflammatory properties. - Expected timeline for improvement: Signs should improve within 48-72 hours; however, continuation depends on clinical response. - Key side effects to monitor: Allergic reactions, gastrointestinal symptoms, lab markers for hepatic or renal function. - Alternative medications if first-line fails: Vancomycin if MRSA is suspected; switch antibiotics based on culture results.  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: I'll include lifestyle and behavioral interventions that enhance outcomes. - Primary non-drug interventions: Elevate the head of the bed, warm compresses to reduce discomfort and swelling. - Patient education priorities: Importance of medication adherence, recognizing worsening symptoms. - Lifestyle modifications: Adequate hydration, rest. - Behavioral interventions: Follow-up compliance, hand hygiene to prevent additional infections.  STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: I'll establish appropriate monitoring and follow-up care. - Follow-up timeline: Reassess within 24-48 hours in the hospital or clinic. - Monitoring parameters: Visual acuity, ocular exam findings, systemic symptoms, temperature, inflammatory markers. - Red flag symptoms: Sudden vision loss, worsening pain, fever recurrence, signs of abscess or intracranial extension. - Treatment response assessment: Clinical improvement in ocular swelling, redness, pain; systemic symptom resolution. STEP 7 - COORDINATION & REFERRALS: What additional care coordination is needed? - Specialist referrals needed: Urgent consultation with an ophthalmologist and infectious disease specialist. - Other healthcare team members: Nursing staff for monitoring, possibly a physical therapist for eye care. - Community resources: Education materials on orbital cellulitis, support groups if appropriate. - Insurance/cost considerations: Verify coverage for hospitalization, IV antibiotics, specialist visits.
